transcript.text: Ugh

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: The air temples will teach her nothing. Only I can give her the training she needs to be a complete Avatar.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I've told you that will not happen!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Hey! I'm right here! Anyone want to ask me what I think?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Korra, please listen.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm tired of listening to you. Both of you. You keep me locked up, telling me you know what's best. But both of you were powerless against the spirit attack.  I think it's time I had a new teacher.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Now Korra—

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Unalaq has proven he's the only one who knows what I need to learn. I have to go with him.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Please, I know you're angry, but we've come so far together.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm sorry, Tenzin. This is as far as we go.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: It has been a pleasure serving you, Avatar Korra.

transcript.speaker: Katara
transcript.text: I think you forgot a couple of things.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Mother, I think I need some time alone with my family right now.

transcript.speaker: Katara
transcript.text: This is your family, Tenzin.  When you get to be my age, you'll be thankful for the time you had with your siblings. Besides, I think it's important that you all visit your father's home together.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Come on! It'll be fun.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: I'm dying to see that laid back, Vacation Tenzin I've heard so much about.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: All right, hop on! I love you, Mom.  We'll see you soon!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Do you think I did the right thing?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I don't know. I'm sorry, but I'm not very good at this Avatar counseling thing. But I know your heart is in the right place. You'll just have to trust it. .

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I know this was a hard decision, Korra, but it was the right one. Now it is time to put it behind you and begin your new training. I have great plans for you.

transcript.speaker: Shiro Shinobi
transcript.text: The Southern Water Tribe is under siege! When Avatar Korra was attacked by a dark spirit, Chief Unalaq was the only one able to stop it. So, Korra turned her back on Tenzin and chose Unalaq as her new spiritual mentor. Tenzin and his family left for a vacation at the Southern Air Temple, while Korra remained in the Water Tribe. Will she be able to restore balance between humans and spirits?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: You're early.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: What can I say? I'm pumped up to learn that Unalaq spirit fighting.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I'm not here to teach you to fight spirits, I'm here to help you begin your spiritual training. We're going to one of the most remote places in the world, the long neglected spiritual center of your tribe, the South Pole.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You're going to train me at the South Pole?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: We will do more than just train. By neglecting the spirits, the people of the South have brought darkness upon themselves, and now it threatens to destroy our tribe. We must set things right. The Southern Water Tribe depends on you.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: A dangerous trip to the South Pole? Count me in!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: There it is, the Southern Air Temple. Isn't it magnificent?

transcript.speaker: Shung
transcript.text: Master Tenzin, welcome!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Good to see you again, Abbot Shung.

transcript.speaker: Shung
transcript.text: Is there anything you need? Water? Dandelion greens? Ahh, perhaps you'd like to recenter yourself by meditating in the gardens?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: No thank you, I'm fine.

transcript.speaker: Shung
transcript.text: And you must be the honorable Pema! Please, accept these gifts.  This is an ancient airbender head shaver we've refurbished just for you.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Oh.  Okay?

transcript.speaker: Shung
transcript.text: And Pema!  These flowers once filled the mountainside! Now, they can brighten up your room.

transcript.speaker: Pema
transcript.text: That's ... sweet? Y-you didn't have to.

transcript.speaker: Shung
transcript.text: Nonsense! Whatever you need is yours. Anything for the mother of the next generation of airbenders.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: No!  That gift is mine!

transcript.speaker: Jinora
transcript.text: You don't even like to read!

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: Eeeh!

transcript.speaker: Pema
transcript.text: Yep, those are the world's next generation of  airbenders.

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Mommy, Daddy, look! I finally got a lemur! I'm gonna name him ... Poki!

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Poki! Come back!

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: S'cuse me, a little help here?

transcript.speaker: Acolyte
transcript.text: Sorry, I thought you were the servants.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: We're Tenzin's brother and sister!

transcript.speaker: Acolyte
transcript.text: Avatar Aang had other children?  The world is filled with more airbenders?

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: We're not airbenders.

transcript.speaker: Acolyte
transcript.text: Oh ...  I'm so sorry.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I thought you said Bolin was coming?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: He said he'd be here, but I can't worry about it. I have to make sure you have everything you need for a safe trip.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Thanks, Captain Expedition, but I'll be fine.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Tonraq, what do you want?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I heard you're taking Korra to the South Pole.  I'm coming.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Absolutely not. You're a distraction to Korra and a hindrance to what needs to be done.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: My daughter is not going without me! She needs someone to watch after her.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Dad, why do you always think you know what's best for me?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Because he's misguided. The sad truth is, it's men like your father who have put the Spirit World out of balance. He's ignored my warnings in the past and hasn't learned since.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: What happened in the past?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: It doesn't matter. What matters is the Everstorm.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: The Everstorm?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: It's a massive blizzard that's battered the South Pole for decades.  I'm coming, unless you think you can stop me.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Guys! Hey, wait for me!

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Check it out,  I'm traveling in style!  Okay, uh, sorry, still getting used to that throttle.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Uh, where'd you get the ride?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Varrick; he's awesome! He also gave me this fancy snowsuit! It's inflatable, with an internal heater, emergency beacon, and food ration pouches! I mean, if I get lost, I can survive in this thing for like, like a month!  Who wants some freeze dried cucumberquats.  Nobody? ... Did I interrupt a conversation?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: No, the conversation is over.  Dad, come if you want, just don't interfere with my training. .

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: Does this sidecar have the capacity for two passengers?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Sure does. But, uh ... who's gonna drive?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Well, what do you know? Looks like--

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Go away, Mako.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: So once we get to the South Pole, then what happens?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: You will open an ancient spirit portal.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm sorry, what now?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: At the South Pole, there is a portal that connects our world to the Spirit World, but it has long been closed.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: And that's why the evil spirits are attacking?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: There are no evil spirits, there is light and dark in them all. But when they're unbalanced, the darkness takes over.  If you can open the portal in time, balance will be restored.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: What do you mean ... in time?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: There's a reason the Glacier Spirits Festival ends on the winter solstice. That's when the Spirit World and the physical world are close together. Only then can the Avatar open the portal.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: The winter solstice is tomorrow.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Exactly, and we can't afford to wait another year.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Easy, Naga.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: What are those?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Dark spirits.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Let's keep moving. We have to find a safe place to set up camp.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Uncle, why do you think the dark spirits are following us?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Can we not talk about dark spirits, please?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: My brother doesn't like ghost stories.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: Don't worry. I will protect you, my feeble turtle duck.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Sadly, this isn't a ghost story. This is real.  The spirits are angry because he's here.  Haven't you ever wondered how your father ended up in the South Pole? Why he's never taken you to visit his homeland in the North?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Unalaq, this is not the time.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: You're right. You should have told her a long time ago.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Told me what!?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I left the North Pole because ... I was banished.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You were banished from the North? Why?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Because I almost destroyed the entire tribe.  Twenty years ago, I was a general in the Northern Water Tribe, sworn to protect my people.

transcript.speaker: Young Unalaq
transcript.text: Brother! We're being attacked!

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I drove them out of the city and deep into the frozen tundra.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: We tracked them deep into an ancient forest. Many believed this forest was the home to spirits, and the barbarians retreated there because they thought we wouldn't attack them on such hallow grounds. They thought wrong.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: We captured the barbarians, but in the process, we destroyed the forest.  I didn't realize the consequences of what I had done.  By destroying the forest, I unknowingly let loose angry spirits.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: They threatened to destroy everything, the entire city.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Unalaq was able to guide the spirits back to the forest. But by then, the damage had been done.  For being the cause of so much devastation, my father banished me from the Northern Water Tribe in shame.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: That's when I came to the South and started a new life.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Whoa, so you  were supposed to be chief, then he  became chief. No wonder you guys don't like each other.  Ow! What? Isn't that what happened?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I can't believe you kept this from me.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I was protecting you from the shame I brought on the family.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Why did you keep hiding things from me and then telling me it's for my own protection? I'm tired of you protecting me!

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Korra!

transcript.speaker: Jinora
transcript.text: Wow, the statue room.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: That's right, Jinora, the most sacred place in the entire Southern Air Temple.  Here, you will find statues of every Avatar who ever lived.  Where are your brother and sister?

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: You can't catch me! I've the greatest air scooter-er of all time!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Meelo!

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Korra, you have every right to be mad at me. But I don't want you to make the same mistake I made. I should never have gone into that forest, and we shouldn't be going to the South Pole now. Spirits and the physical world should remain separate.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Dad, it's my job to be the bridge between the spirits and the physical world, and I finally have a chance to live up to my potential.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: You don't even know if what Unalaq says is true.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: You want proof? Look to the sky. Where I'm from, the spirits are at peace and they light up the dark.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: The Northern Lights.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Yes. There used to be lights at the South as well, but during the Hundred Year War, the South was thrown out of balance and the lights disappeared. When the War ended, the North helped to rebuild you physically , as a nation, but we have not rebuilt you spiritually. Now the spirits no longer dance in your skies. Instead, they rampage in the Everstorm.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I think we're here.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Is that what I think it is?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: We must keep moving.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Oh man, I really don't like this.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Bolin, just stay calm, there's no reason to-  panic!

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Korra, look out!

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Oh, it's in the engine!  Aaaahhhhh!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Is everyone okay?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Aaaahhhhh!

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: I can't stop it!

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: I'll save you.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: I'm a raft!

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Uhhh, can someone please deflate me?  Thank you.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Oh, great. There goes our equipment. Now what are we supposed to do?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: There's only one thing to do. We have to turn back.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: No! The solstice is tonight. And we're so close.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: This mission is too dangerous. We're leaving.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: No, Dad, you're leaving.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Don't worry sir, I'll keep an eye on Korra for you.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Thank you, Mako.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Let's open this portal and lead your father and the entire Southern Water Tribe in the right direction. We don't have much time.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Then what are we waiting for?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: So, what exactly were you and my dad talking about?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Nothing, he was just worried about you, that's all.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Y'know, sometimes I wonder whose side you're on.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: There aren't any sides. We all just want to help however we can. You have to trust that we're here for you.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: We've arrived.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Trees frozen in the ice.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: It's just like the sacred forest Tonraq destroyed in the North.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: So, what do I do?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: You must find your way to the heart of the forest where the dormant spirit portal lies. From here, you're on your own.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Wait a second, there's no way she's going alone.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Yeah! If she goes,  we go, too!

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: The Avatar must go alone.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: But I don't have any connection with the spirits. In fact, it seems like they hate me.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: You have to believe in yourself, like I believe in you.  What is it?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I guess I'm just so used to people telling me how to do things that I forgot what it was like to have someone trust in me.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Korra, all the past Avatars live on inside of you. Let them guide you. Let them help you find the light in the dark.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Wait here, I'll be okay.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Good luck.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: The spirit portal. Amazing.

transcript.speaker: Jinora
transcript.text: Whoa. What Avatar is this?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: The light in the dark.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Why isn't it opening?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Come on portal, open!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: The spirits, dancing in the sky.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I can't believe it.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: It's beautiful.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: She did it.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Hey, Korra, you're back.  Hey, Korra's back!

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: Why are you initiating physical contact with another woman?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Everything you said was true.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Avatar Korra, you have taken the first step in bringing balance back to the South, and soon the whole world.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: You never cease to amaze me.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Thanks. By the way, I'm really sorry for being a total pain. Things were really stressful and pretty confusing. It's hard being the Avatar.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: It's harder being the Avatar's boyfriend.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: What are all your Northern troops doing here?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Opening the spirit portal was only the first step in getting the Southern Water Tribe back on its righteous path. There's more difficult work to be done before our two tribes are truly united.

transcript.speaker: Shiro Shinobi
transcript.text: Korra has reopened the Southern spirit portal and taken the first step to restoring balance between spirits and man. Meanwhile, tensions are high between Korra and her father after she discovered he was hiding a dark secret. Years ago, Tonraq was banished from the North. And now the Northern navy has landed on Southern shores. What other plans does Unalaq have for the Avatar?

transcript.speaker: Northern soldier
transcript.text: Everyone, clear the streets! Get back in your homes.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Uncle, why did you bring your troops down from the North?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Now that you've opened the Southern portal, we need to protect it from the people who would do the spirits harm.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I can protect it.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I need you for something more important. There is another portal, in the North. Once you open it, spirits and man will be able to move freely between the North and the South in a matter of seconds.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: But, the solstice is over. How am I going to open it?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: The spiritual energy is much stronger in the North. And now that you've opened the Southern portal, your energy is stronger as well.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: With both portals open, our tribes will be united again.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: The world will be united again.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Ahh, I haven't felt this at peace since-  Aaand, it's over.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Gooood morning, Universe.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Bumi, please, cover yourself.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Well, lookee here, "Vacation Tenzin" has finally decided to join us.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Yes, he has.  It's so nice to get to spend more time with my family.  Isn't that right, my little Rohan?  And I've really enjoyed having you two around. Reminds me of all those great vacations we took as kids with Dad.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Uhh, I think your memory's a little foggy.  Bumi and I weren't on those great vacations. It was always just you and Dad.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: No, that can't be right. What about the time he took us to Kyoshi Island to ride the elephant koi?

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Nope, we weren't there.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Hmm. Oh, remember Ember Island? Those amazing sand palaces we built on the beach.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: You mean, you built? We never saw the place.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: I could've sworn.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Morning, kids!

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Morning, Uncle Bumi!  Do you have a baby in there?

transcript.speaker: Pema
transcript.text: Where's your sister?

transcript.speaker: Jinora
transcript.text: Who?

transcript.speaker: Pema
transcript.text: Ikki. About this tall.  Talks real fast. I'm sure you know her.

transcript.speaker: Jinora
transcript.text: Uhh ...

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: There was a lemur fight, but the bison told us not to worry because a giant was coming. Then we almost got eaten by a shark-squid!

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: The shark-squid? He's here? It appears my old nemesis has found me.

transcript.speaker: Pema
transcript.text: Jinora, were you and Meelo teasing your sister again?

transcript.speaker: Jinora
transcript.text: I don't know.  Maybe.  Yes.

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: She ran away.

transcript.speaker: Pema
transcript.text: Honestly , I don't know why you kids can't just get along!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: It's all right, dear, Ikki couldn't have gone far.,  I'll find her.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Commander Bumi reporting for duty! Search-and-rescue missions are my specialty.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: What do you say we all go together?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Sure, I could use the help.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: When I get back, we'll come out with a plan to take down that shark-squid once and for all!

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Yeah!

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Thank you for coming, everyone. I know these last few days have been very troubling.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Troubling? Troubling is when I get that itchy rash that won't go away, and Zhu Li's not around to scratch it. This is shocking.  Nay, sickening! But these kale cookies? Opposite.  Remind me to get the recipe later.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: What's your point, Varrick?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: My point is,  Unalaq's already booted our chieftains out of their palace. How long before he starts telling us what kind of cookies  we can eat?

transcript.speaker: Zhu Li
transcript.text: Probably a couple of days.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Rhetorical question, Zhu Li, you gotta keep up.  Not to mention, I've got a cargo ship full of halibut that's rotting thanks to this harbor lockdown?  Who wants to buy a ship full of stinking fish?  Seriously, it's not rhetorical. I need to sell these fish.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Chief Unalaq is here to help the South. He wants to show us how to restore balance with the spirits so they'll stop attacking.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: The only spirit I'm interested in restoring is our spirit of independence . Am I right, people?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: All Unalaq is trying to do is make our tribes unified again.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: No, he wants control of our wealth. My wealth. And I like my wealth. If Unalaq doesn't pull his forces out, then we have no choice but to fight for our freedom !

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You want to start a war? Are you crazy?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Unalaq started this, not us.  I'm sorry, maybe you could speak with your uncle. Tell him how frustrated we all are. He'll listen to what the Avatar has to say. Do it for me?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'll do it for the tribe.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: I cannot stop eating these things.  Look, we all know where this conflict is heading. We need to start preparing for war .

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: I will hate to leave this quaint tribe.

transcript.speaker: Desna
transcript.text: Is that true, Eska?

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: Of course not, Desna, I will not miss it at all. I hold immense dislike for the South.  Bolin, laugh at my humorous quip!

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Yes, dear.  So-so funny.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: You know, I'll be really sad when you have to leave. It's been really great getting to know you.  Really.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: But you will be coming with me to the North. There we will live the rest of our lives together in icy bliss.  Foolish Bolin.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Mako! I'm so happy to see you!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Uh, you all right, bro?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: No! No, I'm not all right. I can't take anymore. Listen, I don't want to live in icy bliss with Eska!  Don't make me. Oh, please, please don't make me.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Uh, hey, if you're that unhappy, just break up with her.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Break up with her? You can do that?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Yeah. Guys do that all the time.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: How?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Just tell her you're not that into her anymore.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Oh, no, no, I don't think she'd like that.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Ending a relationship is kind of like pulling off a blood-sucking leech. You just gotta rip it off and get it over with. You'll feel a lot better afterwards. Trust me.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Thanks, Mako. Whew. I'm lucky you're so good at breaking girls' hearts.  Ha, Korra better watch out.  Oooh, no, it's just a-, uh, you kn-, uh, never mind.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Our next training sessions isn't until tomorrow.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm sorry to interrupt. It's about our conversation this morning.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Yes?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I understand why you brought your troops here, but I'm afraid it's sending the wrong message.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Your father has been talking to you.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Not just him. Varrick too. There was a meeting at my parents' house. A lot of Southerners feel like their tribe is being invaded.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I am their chief. I'm uniting, not invading.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I know, but I'm just afraid if something doesn't change, there could be a civil war.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: If the Water Tribes were at war, the other nations would take sides. The dark spirits would thrive off this negative energy, and the world would be thrown into a battle between spirits and man. That would be catastrophic.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: How do we stop it?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: We? No, Korra.  This is a war only the Avatar can prevent.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm usually the one starting fights. I don't know how to stop them from happening.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: As the Avatar, you must remain neutral in this conflict. You will naturally want to help your people, but showing favoritism will not help our tribes finds unity.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Maybe Tenzin was right.  Maybe I'm not ready to be the Avatar.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Tenzin lacked faith in you.  But I have no doubt that you will become the most admired Avatar the world has ever known.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Thank you, Uncle.

transcript.speaker: Northern soldier
transcript.text: Who threw those?

transcript.speaker: Northern soldier
transcript.text: You hoodlums think you're tough, huh?

transcript.speaker: Southern civilian
transcript.text: Pick on a waterbender your own size!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Stop!

transcript.speaker: Southern civilian
transcript.text: Tell these thugs to go back to the North. They're not welcome here anymore!

transcript.speaker: Northern soldier
transcript.text: These Southerners need to stay in line.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Everyone, calm down. You're all part of the same tribe, start acting like it.

transcript.speaker: Southern civilian
transcript.text: You're taking their side? We thought you were one of us.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm not taking anyone's side.  Hey!

transcript.speaker: Little girl
transcript.text: You're the worst Avatar ever!

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Everyone, walk away from this. They're not worth our trouble. Go back to your homes.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Korra, I-  Korra!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Ikki! Ikki! Ikki? Ikki, where are you?

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Over here, Dad!  Just kidding. It's me!

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: There's no sign of her anywhere.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Why would Ikki run off like this? Ah, it's probably my fault.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Probably.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Excuse me?

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: I'm guessing you've been so busy with your  "duty" to Republic City that you forgot about your duty to your kids.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: "Duty."

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: What are you, five years old?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Kya, you're right. I haven't been spending enough time with them. I wish I could be as good a father as Dad was to us.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Tenzin, your problem is you're exactly like Dad. He was so focused on saving the world and doing his duty,  don't laugh, that he never had time for us.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Dad was under a lot of pressure.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: He always had time for you, though,  his precious little airbender.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Dad loved us all equally . Besides, it all happened a long time ago. Why are we even talking about this?

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Because you seem to have some grandiose delusion that we had a perfect, happy-go-lucky childhood. Guess what. We didn't!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: We need to keep moving if we want to find Ikki before dark.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: See what he's doing there, Bumi? Classic airbender technique. Cutting and running when things get tough!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Uch.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Yeah. Did Dad teach you that move?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: How was your day, sweetie?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Oh, fabulous.  My tribe's about to go to war, and I'm supposed to stop it, but will anyone listen to me? No! And I didn't ask for my father's help. Can't he just let me be the Avatar?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Uh, do you want advice, or am I just supposed to listen? I'm still not clear on that.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Ugh. I'm sorry. My dad just gets me all worked up.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: How about you take a break from all this Avatar stuff, and we go out for a quiet dinner. Just the two of us.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Isn't this fun, huh? We never get to spend enough time together, just the ... five of us. So fun.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: Excuse us while we retrieve more sustenance.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: You guys gotta save me.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I though you were breaking up with her. What happened to "ripping off the leech"?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: I tried! But anytime I bring up the subject, she threatens to freeze me in a block of ice and feed me to dolphin piranhas!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: So it was more like you tugged at the leech.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Yes, over and over and over, but it won't come off. Why didn't you warn me your cousin had the power to reach into my heart and crush my soul with her bare hands.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Uh, 'cause I thought it was pretty obvious?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: No, no, not to me it wasn't. I'm very bad at reading people. You should know that by now.  Oh, man. Oh! Do something, Avatar!

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: You know, this reminds me of a search-and-rescue mission I commanded years ago in the mountains outside of Ba Sing Se.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Here we go.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: For five days we scoured the beast of a mountain, fighting our ways through blizzards, sandstorms, and three typhoons. Finally, we found the men huddled in a cave, seconds from death. With no time to lose, I piled all twelve of those poor souls on my back and single-handedly carried them down the mountain to safety.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: And how exactly is that supposed to help us find Ikki?

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: It was supposed to inspire you. Clearly, you know nothing about being a leader of men. That's probably why the Avatar fired you.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: I'm sick of your far-fetched tales. Three typhoons?

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Well, I may have thrown in an extra typhoon or two for dramatic effect, but-

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Quit arguing and bring that lantern over here. I found footprints.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Come on!

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: No, follow me! This will get us down fifty times faster.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Bumi, it's pitch black and the rocks are slippery. You're going to hurt yourself.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Come on, you wimps! If I can do it, it should be no problem for a couple of benders.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Fine.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: You were right, Bumi! That was faster!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: At least fifty times faster, by my calculations.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Oh, so Tenzin's the funny guy now.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: If you need an airlift down, just say the word.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Bah, I don't need your help. I've got everything under control.  Agh!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Bumi!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Did Dad send you to talk to me?

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: Your father doesn't know I'm here.  Korra, what's going on between you two?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Ask Dad.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: I've tried, but he won't talk about it. Honey, it breaks my heart to see our family being torn apart like this.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You want to know what's been going on? I found out Dad's been lying to me my whole life . Unalaq told me everything; how Dad and Tenzin kept me trapped down here while I trained; how Dad got banished from the North.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: So, the truth is out.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You knew? And you never said anything.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: We were trying to keep our family together, to give you a normal childhood.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I never wanted a normal childhood. All I ever wanted to be was the Avatar. But everyone keeps holding me back, even my own parents! Unalaq's the only one who believes in me.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: That's not true, Korra.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: No? Then why is everyone in the South turning against me, when all I'm trying to do is help them?

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: The problems between the North and the South started long before you were born. You can't expect to undo them in a day.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: So I should just sit back and let the Water Tribes go to war?

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: No, but this situation might be out of your control. Varrick's been plotting a rebellion against Unalaq. He asked your father to join, and-

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Dad is part of a rebellion?

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: I don't know, but I don't want you getting caught in the middle of it.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: It's too late, Mom. I'm already in the middle of it.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: Korra!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Uncle!  Oh, no. Uncle?  Dad?  Dad, don't do this.

transcript.speaker: Rebel
transcript.text: Turn around, Avatar, and pretend you didn't see anything.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: No. Leave Unalaq and go. I'll tell him I tried to stop you, but you escaped. We can still avoid a war.

transcript.speaker: Rebel
transcript.text: No, we can't.

transcript.speaker: Rebel
transcript.text: Get him out of here!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: We're all part of the same tribe. I don't wanna hurt you.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Dad, stop!  Why did you do this, Dad?  What? Who are you? Where's my father?

transcript.speaker: Rebel leader
transcript.text: He wouldn't help us. He's a traitor, just like you.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Thank you for saving my life.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm just glad I got here in time.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Find Varrick. I want him to freeze in prison with the rest of these traitors.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Wait, you can't just lock them away. That will only make the South angrier.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: You want them to go free?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: No. But let them stand trial for what they did. Every Water Tribe citizen deserves that right.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Very well. I will respect the Avatar's wishes in this matter.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Thank you, Uncle.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: I told you those rocks were slippery. You're lucky you didn't kill yourself.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: You done with the lecture, Mom ?

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Oh, grow up! You haven't changed one bit since we were kids. You're still trying to prove you can do everything a bender can. Well, you can't. Deal with it.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: And you're not our mother. You don't get to tell me what I can and can't do. Deal with that.  Ugh.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Good luck healing yourself with your special nonbending powers.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Hey, hey, back me up here, Tenzin.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Kya's right. You're the oldest of us, but you always acted like the youngest. I had to become the responsible one.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: You think you're the responsible one?  Where were you after Dad died and Mom was all alone? Because I was the only one who packed up and moved my whole life to be with her.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Sure, after years of flitting around the world, trying to find yourself. It was time for you to settle down somewhere.  You two have no idea how it feels to have the future of an entire culture on your shoulders.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Oh, boo-hoo. Must've been real hard for you, flying around the world with Dad, riding elephant koi all day.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Oh, so that's what this is all about.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: That's what it's always been about. You think you're some savior who has to carry on Dad's legacy.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Who else is going to do it?

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: How about all of us?

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Yeah, we're Aang's kids too.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: We never should have come on this vacation.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: I couldn't agree more.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Well, I didn't want you to come in the first place. I can't be around you two right now. Go back to the temple and see if Ikki returned. I'll keep looking out here.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Fine.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Fine.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Fine.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Is it okay if I come in?

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: Of course. We heard what happened. Are you okay?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm so glad you weren't there. I don't know what I would've done.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I had no idea how far Varrick was willing to go. My brother and I have our differences, but I would never attack him.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm sorry for thinking you had anything to do with the rebels. And for all the pain I've caused you and Mom.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I'm the one who should apologize. After I saw the Southern Lights return, I was so proud of you. I never should've held you back.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: When your father and I found each other, all we wanted was to live a simple life and raise a family. But, then we discovered you were the Avatar, and simple was over. We knew one day the world would need you, and you wouldn't need us anymore.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Mom, Dad,  of course I still need you.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: We weren't expecting you.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Tonraq, Senna, you are under arrest and will stand trial.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Trial? For what?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: For conspiring to assassinate me.

transcript.speaker: Shiro Shinobi
transcript.text: Tensions between the Northern and Southern Water Tribes have reached a breaking point. After Chief Unalaq's troops took over the South, Varrick incited an uprising. But Korra stopped the rebels from abducting her uncle. Enraged by the insurrection, Unalaq arrested the rebels and Korra's parents, accusing them of conspiring to assassinate him. Will Korra be able to save her parents and prevent civil war?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You're making a mistake.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I wish it hadn't come to this. But your parents held meeting with the rebels, right here in their home.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I can't believe you're doing this to your own family.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Rest assured, I've appointed Judge Hotah to oversee the trial. He is the most fair and honorable man I know.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Uncle, my parents had nothing to do with the men who attacked you.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I'm sure you're right. So we should have nothing to worry about.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I hope so.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Where's Varrick? We should've closed our deal an hour ago.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Would you relax? This place is great.  And the best part about it,  Eska doesn't know I'm here.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Ee-yah.  I wasn't hiding. Hey, hey-hey, hey.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: I'm not on the hunt for you.  Currently.

transcript.speaker: Desna
transcript.text: We search for Varrick. Our father wishes him to stand trial.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: What did he do?

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: He is a traitor to the Water Tribe, along with our aunt and uncle.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: What?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Korra's parents were arrested?

transcript.speaker: Desna
transcript.text: Yes. Your powers of deduction are impressive.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Yeah, he's a cop.

transcript.speaker: Northern guardsman
transcript.text: Varrick's not here.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: Very well. Desna, let us continue our search elsewhere.  Boyfriend! Bow to me when I exit.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Yes, yes, my sweet koala otter.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: You are so cute when you grovel.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Don't let her treat you that way. Stand up for yourself.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: I tried to break up with her, but Mako gave me terrible advice. Thank you, Mako.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Wait, how are your girl problems my fault?

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Bolin, you need to be honest with her. Tell her how you really feel.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Honesty is for fools, kid.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Varrick?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: If you want to ditch this girl, then make yourself scarce. Disappear, like I did.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Where are you?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Somewhere Unalaq will never find me.  Inside Ping-Ping! How we doin'?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: The coast is clear. You can come out.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: No way, mister. Not until I know it's absolutely 157% safe.  Ah! Thank you, Zhu Li.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Your assistant's in there too?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Zhu Li never leaves my side.  Yuck! Pyugh! Pyuck! You forgot the honey!

transcript.speaker: Zhu Li
transcript.text: Sorry, sir. There isn't any in here.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: No honey? We're in a bear for crying out loud!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I'm gonna go see how Korra's doing.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Bolin, I got a little something for you 'round back.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Wow!

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Now listen up. Unalaq's rigged this trial, no doubt about it. So I need you to make sure my trusty rebels stay out of prison.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: What's the money for?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Bribery, of course! There's always someone willing to look the other way for a few yuans.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: I think I catch your drift, Varrick-bear.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Ikki! Ikki, where are you? Shoo!  Go bother someone else. You two are worse than Kya and Bumi.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: Okay, everybody here?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Ikki! Oh, thank goodness.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: Juniper Lightning bug, paws off the table!  This is going to be a civilized breakfast. Daddy always says a blessing before we eat, so ...  be quiet and listen up!  We are thankful for this super yummy food and for being the best-est new friends in the world.  But we are most thankful because Meelo and Jinora aren't here,  because they stink.  Oh! Hi, Daddy. I guess you found me. Do I have to go now?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Actually, is there room for one more?

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: Uh, sure. You can sit next to Blueberry Spicehead.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Nice to meet you, Blueberry Spicehead.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: And that's Princess Rainbow, and that's Twinkle Starchild, and that's Juniper Lightning Bug. They're my new brothers and sisters.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: New ones, huh? Can they be my new brothers and sisters too?

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: Maybe, but only if they say it's okay.  Uh-huh, uh-huh. No, no, he's nice. They say it's okay.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: We're good to go. I gave all the money to some guys over there. I told them to "take care of it", and then I winked.  Pretty sure they got the message.

transcript.speaker: Law clerk
transcript.text: This trial will now come to order! Judge Hotah presiding.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Man! I should have paid him!

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Yeah, you think?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I was asleep in my chambers when the rebels attacked. They overpowered me, and the next thing I remember was waking up in the snow after Avatar Korra had saved me.

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: According to Unalaq's testimony, you attended a meeting where Varrick tried to incite a civil war. Is that true?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Yes.

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: And where these men present at that meeting?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Well, yes, but -

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: And where exactly did this meeting take place?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Objection!

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: Quiet down out there! I'll ask you one more time. Where did the meeting happen?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: My parents' house.

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: And who led this meeting?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Your honor, if I may?

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: May what?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: May I ... declare a mistrial?

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: Sit down!  Varrick and your father led the meeting, didn't they?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: My parents are innocent!

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: I've heard all I need to. I'll return shortly with my decision.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Hey there, Eska, I was wondering if we could talk.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: I grant you permission to speak freely.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Oh, good, because I just need to be honest with you. You know, when we first met, there was this crazy spark. But I'm starting to feel like that spark is fading.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: I agree. It is as if a great chasm has formed between us and nothing can bridge it.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Oh! Oh, yes! I'm so glad you understand!

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: Nothing, that is, except marriage.  We will wed at sunset. You may express your joy through tears.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Oh, no, I can't -  This is really tight.

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: Senna, please step forward.  I have found you ... innocent. You are free to go.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: Korra!

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: On the charge of treason, you are all found ... guilty. The punishment for this crime ... is death.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You can't do this!  You take their lives, and I'll take yours!

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Korra, calm down. I'll talk to him.  I know I promised to respect whatever decision you made, but I must ask you to reconsider. Show these men and my brother mercy.

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: Very well. I'll change their punishment. Your lives will be spared, but you will live them out in prison.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Thank you, Uncle.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: You like that, don't you, Blueberry Spicehead?  Yes, you do.  You know, I could get used to it here. No one's yelling at me or telling me I'm delusional.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: We should have Uncle Bumi and Aunt Kya come visit. I bet they'd like it too.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Let's not. They'll only spoil our good mood.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: What do you mean? Aunt Kya is super nice and pretty and always asks me how I'm feeling, and Uncle Bumi is, like, the funniest person in the world .

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: But what about Meelo? He's hilarious too, you never know what's going to come out of his mouth. And Jinora can be so sweet and gentle.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: And mean. And bossy.  Being part of a family is hard, huh, Daddy?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: I couldn't agree with you more.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: But, I guess the nice part about a family is they'll always be there for you. Even though  Twinkle Starchild and Princess Rainbow fight, they still love each other.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: That's very wise of you, Ikki.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: We should probably head back, huh?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: I suppose. We can't hide in this cave forever.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: Don't worry, Daddy. We'll come back and visit Blueberry Spicehead. I know you really bonded with her.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Yes, I'd like that.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: Honey, are you all right?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I'm fine.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Good, let's bust you out of here right now.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Korra, no. Saving me would start a war. If fighting were to break out, the North would crush the South. I'll be all right. Just promise me you won't do anything rash.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Fine. I promise.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: It's okay, Mom.

transcript.speaker: Senna
transcript.text: I-I hate feeling so helpless.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I know.

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: What do you want?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: It's not about what I want. It's about what Naga wants.  And she'd like you to let my father out of prison.

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: I-I'm sorry, but there is nothing I can do. I was just following Unalaq's orders.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: What are you talking about?

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: I-I've said too much.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Unless you wanna be Naga's afternoon snack, you'd better keep talking.

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: I-I've worked for your uncle for years! He said he needed everyone to think the trial was fair.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: So Unalaq told you what to say?

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: Yes! Every word.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Then why did he have you free my mother and change your sentence?

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: He's trying to keep you on his side. But he also wants your father out of the way. Just like when he got your father banished.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: What do you mean, "he got my father banished"?

transcript.speaker: Hotah
transcript.text: Nothing!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Keep talking.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Uh ... Hey there, Dad. You're looking well.  Look, uh, I'm sorry I didn't turn out to be an airbender like you hoped. But I've tried my best to keep the world safe. Hope I made you proud.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Of course he'd be proud of you, Bumi.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Kya! I-I was just,  uh ... cleaning off Dad's statue.  It's so dusty in here.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: Come here.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Thanks, Kya. You always know when I need a hug.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Unalaq's a liar and a traitor!

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: I've been trying to tell you that from the get-go.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: What happened?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I found out the truth about my dad's banishment. Unalaq hired the barbarians to attack their tribe. Then he told them to hide in the spirit forest, knowing my dad would go after them.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Unalaq wanted your dad out of the way so he could become chief. It was a setup.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Just like the whole trial. I can't believe I trusted him. I'm busting my father and the rebels out of jail. I need your help.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: If you do this, there's no going back.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I know. Will you help me or not?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Of course, I'll help.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Me too.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Count me in!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I don't even want to know.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: So I'm guessing the breakup with Eska didn't go well?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: No, no, the honesty thing worked out great. So great she decided we should  get married!

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Sorry.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm pretty sure the guy is supposed to give the girl the betrothal necklace.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: I guess Eska didn't get the memo.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Look, the only way to deal with crazy women is to lie big and leave fast. Lucky for you, Varrick's got your back. Now, gather 'round Ping-Ping. Let's talk plan.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: My dad's in there.  Where is he?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I'm sorry, Korra. You'll never see your father again.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Where's my father?

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: On a ship headed to the Northern Tribe. He'll serve out his sentence there.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Bring him back. Or I'm taking you out and the rest of your army.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Remember who you are. As the Avatar, you cannot threaten war. You must remain neutral, or our tribes will never find unity.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You don't want unity. You want power. You've always been jealous of my father, haven't you? You got him banished so you could become chief, and I bet it just killed you to learn he was the Avatar's father. No wonder you kept trying to take me away from him.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: All I've ever wanted is to help you realize your destiny.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Well, I don't want your help anymore.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: If you start a war, the dark spirits will annihilate the South. And even I will be powerless to stop them.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm done being manipulated by you. You're going to bring my father back, then you and your troops will return to the North.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: And why would I do that?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Because you still need me to open the Northern portal.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: No, I don't. You've served your purpose.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: If we get to Varrick's boat, we can still save your father.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Let's go.

transcript.speaker: Northern soldier
transcript.text: You have a license for that animal?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Uh, you fellas seen a traveling circus come through here?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Zhu Li, do the thing.

transcript.speaker: Excited man
transcript.text: That platypus bear is pooping money!

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Where's your dad?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: On a ship headed north. Think we can catch up to it?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Sure, once you get us past our friends from the North.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: If only we had a plane to get me close to those ships. I could waterbend them out of the way.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: A plane? Well, why didn't you say so?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Um, why do you have a plane on your boat?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: In case the boat sinks, of course.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: But there's no runway. How are we supposed to take off?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Zhu Li! Take a note: "Build runway".

transcript.speaker: Zhu Li
transcript.text: Yes, sir.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I have an idea.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Now!

transcript.speaker: Helmsman
transcript.text: Captain, you'll never gonna believe this.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: There! My dad's on that ship!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Jump!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Where are the prisoners?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: Korra, this is crazy. You promised me you wouldn't do anything rash.

transcript.speaker: Korra,
transcript.text: I had to. I'll explain later.

transcript.speaker: Pema
transcript.text: Sweetie!  You're okay! Oh!  I was so worried!  Do you have something you wanna say to your sister?

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Ikki, I'm glad you're back.

transcript.speaker: Jinora
transcript.text: Yeah, sorry we made fun of you.

transcript.speaker: Ikki
transcript.text: Thanks. Wanna play airball?

transcript.speaker: Jinora
transcript.text: Sure!

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Yeah!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: I wanted to apologize for how I acted yesterday. I've worked so hard to celebrate Dad's legacy that I may have overlooked the parts of him that were less than ideal.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: And we're sorry for dumping our frustrations with Dad out on you.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: Yeah, you didn't deserve that.

transcript.speaker: Kya
transcript.text: I thought you two might wanna see this.  Mom gave it to me before we left.

transcript.speaker: Bumi
transcript.text: That is one good-looking family, huh?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: That's one happy family.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: So once I knew the truth, I couldn't sit by and do nothing.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: My own brother betrayed me. And our entire tribe.

transcript.speaker: Rebel leader
transcript.text: What's our next move?

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I've been running from my past for too long. It's time to put my brother in his place.

transcript.speaker: Rebel leader
transcript.text: You have our support, Chief Tonraq.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Mine too. I'll be proud to fight alongside you, Dad.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: No, Korra.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: But you said the South doesn't stand a change against Unalaq's forces. I can help.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: The best way for you to help is by getting the president of the United Republic on our side. The South can give Unalaq a good fight for a while. But we'll need the United Forces in order to win this war.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: All right, I'll get you all the help you need. I love you, Dad.

transcript.speaker: Tonraq
transcript.text: I love you, too.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: I really need to thank you, Korra.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: For what? I started a civil war.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Exactly! Now Eska and I are officially broken up.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Oh, looks like we have company! And not the fun kind!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: What is that?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: That would be my darling Eska. Quick question: is this thing fast enough to get away from my crazy waterbending ex-girlfriend?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Why do you think I built this boat?

transcript.speaker: Shiro Shinobi
transcript.text: It's brother versus brother in the war of the Water Tribes. After Korra discovered that Chief Unalaq betrayed her and her father, she turned against him, sparking civil war. The Southern rebels rallied around Tonraq, but they are vastly outnumbered, so Korra is headed to Republic City to seek aid. But will she be able to convince President Raiko to send troops to help the South?

transcript.speaker: Lin
transcript.text: Welcome home, Avatar.  Thanks for starting a war.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I didn't start a war. Well, I did, but it's more complicated than you're making it seem.

transcript.speaker: Lin
transcript.text: Mako, I want you back on the beat. There's going to be a Southern Water Tribe peace march tonight. I need you there to make sure things don't get out of hand.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I'm all yours.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'll go too. The people of the South need to see that the Avatar is on their side in the fight against the Northern invaders.

transcript.speaker: Lin
transcript.text: Great, that should calm them down.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Maybe you should sit this out.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: What?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I just think having you there blatantly supporting one side will only make things worse. You could at least try to seem neutral.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm not neutral! The North invaded my home. The only reason I'm here is to get the Republic to send troops to help the South.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Zhu Li's already scheduled a meeting for us with President Raiko tomorrow. We'll get them on board.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Whatever, I gotta go to work.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: I better go check on my factory.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I'm going to find out about this peace march.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: And I am dying for a pedicure.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: So, um, what should I be doing?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I don't know, Bolin. Figure something out.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Say, kid, have you ever seen Republic City at night?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Sure, I live here.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Have you really seen it?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Y- no?

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: That's what I thought. Come on.

transcript.speaker: General
transcript.text: Tonraq and the rebels are holed up here in the hills outside of town.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: Leave them. My brother's no threat to us up there. Increase security around the spirit portal. Keeping it safe is our number one priority.

transcript.speaker: General
transcript.text: Yes, sir!

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I need you two to go after the Avatar. She's the only one who can open the Northern spirit portal.

transcript.speaker: Desna
transcript.text: But Father, you told Korra-

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I told Korra what I thought she needed to hear.

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: I'll find her.  She stole my husband.

transcript.speaker: Unalaq
transcript.text: I need her alive .

transcript.speaker: Eska
transcript.text: Fine.

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Watch me, Poki.  You lie down and roll over.  Roll. Over.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: No, no, you can't just demonstrate it. That never works.

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Good!

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Ugh, classic over-rewarding.

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Poki, where are you going?

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Command respect.  Having some trouble, son?

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Poki isn't very good at learning.

transcript.speaker: Tenzin
transcript.text: Believe me, I know the feeling. Maybe I can help. How would you like your old dad to teach you how to be a master trainer?

transcript.speaker: Meelo
transcript.text: Yeah!

transcript.speaker: Reporter
transcript.text: Tensions are running up high outside of the Southern Water Tribe Cultural Center. The Avatar is leading a group of Southerners in a peaceful protest against Chief Unalaq, but the Northerners have come out in droves in support of their leader.

transcript.speaker: Northern protesters
transcript.text: Boo! Get out of here! Boo! Get a real job! Get out of here!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Hey! Stop! Republic City Police!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: The Northern Water Tribe is out of control!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I saw a firebender running away from the blast. The North might not be responsible for this.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Of course, they're responsible. Who else would it be?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Wow. Usually, when I see flashing lights like this, it's because I got hit in the head with a rock.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Being famous is like getting hit with a rock all the time.

transcript.speaker: Spectator
transcript.text: Look! It's Bolin!

transcript.speaker: Shiro Shinobi
transcript.text: Folks, that cheer you're hearing is for local favorite, Bolin, of the Fire Ferrets. Let's see if we can get a quick interview. Bolin!  Bolin, the Fire Ferrets are out for the season. How have you been spending your time lately?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Well, I took a trip South for the Glacier Spirits Festival, was briefly engaged to a princess, then went through kind of a tough breakup there, was accidentally involved in a civil war ...  But there's nowhere I'd rather be than pro-bending night in Republic City! Am I right, people? Republic City!

transcript.speaker: Shiro Shinobi
transcript.text: Do you miss being in the ring?

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Well, I definitely don't miss getting hit with things all the time, and the humiliating losing. I mean, that gets pretty old. You know, sometimes I actually cry myself to sleep ...  I guess what I miss the most are these fans ! They're the greatest fans in the world ! Give it up for the fans!

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Look how these people love you, kid! They're eating that cornball spiel right out of your hand.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: The trick is, whenever I get confused, I just say "Republic City" or "fans", and then everyone cheers.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: I think I just figured out your true calling.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I hope President Raiko listens to us.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Don't worry. I was a big contributor to his election campaign. Him and the other guy. Gotta hedge your bets.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Hello, Mr. President.  Sir, the Southern Water Tribe-

transcript.speaker: Raiko
transcript.text: Just a second. Keep smiling.

transcript.speaker: Raiko
transcript.text: Now, how can I help the Avatar and my most generous supporter?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Unalaq's troops have invaded the South. We need you to send the United Forces to help.

transcript.speaker: Raiko
transcript.text: I'm very concerned by what's happening down there. But I don't think it's the Republic's place to interfere with internal Water Tribe matters.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Unalaq isn't even the rightful ruler of the Water Tribe. He lied his way onto the Northern throne.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Mr. President, the Republic is already involved in this conflict. The North attacked our cultural center last night.

transcript.speaker: Raiko
transcript.text: Believe me, we are doing everything we can to bring the people responsible to justice.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: "The people responsible"? Who else would it be but the Northerners?

transcript.speaker: Raiko
transcript.text: Now, I know that when you're young, it's hard to keep perspective-

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: You're the one who's lost perspective. I'm trying to save my tribe, and you're taking pictures.

transcript.speaker: Raiko
transcript.text: Sending troops is not something I can do at this time. But I promise I will work with Unalaq and the South for a diplomatic solution. Now, I'm sorry, but my mind is made up. This meeting is over.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: My family is going to be wiped out, and it'll be on your head for doing nothing about it.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I can't believe the President is doing nothing! H-He doesn't even care!

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I'm sure he cares, but he can't just tell his people to go fight a battle at the South Pole that has nothing to do with them.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: How could you take his side?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: What's with you and sides? Why do you always think I'm working against you?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Well, you're not helping me! I'm trying to get troops to the South. What are you doing?

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: I'm doing my job .

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Well, excuse me , officer. Don't let me stand in the way of you writing tickets. I'm just trying to save the world.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: Well, you wouldn't have to if you didn't keep messing it up!

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I can't talk to you when you're like this.

transcript.speaker: Mako
transcript.text: You're the one who's like this!

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Huh?  Hey! In a hurry?

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: Sorry, I have to talk to Varrick.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: Yeah, me too.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Oh, hello!  See? I told you I could do it.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Sorry I ever doubted you.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: We can't wait for the President to act. We need those troops now .

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: And my company is about to go under. I have to find a way to make some sales.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Right, okay. Got it. Idea storm!  Get the supplies!  You're about to get an inside look at how Varrick Global Industries stays at the forefront of imagination innovation, or "imagivation"! That's trademarked, pal.  Brainwork requires increased circulation.  Let's do this!  Okay, here come the ideas. Fast and furious. Pink mint lemon tea. Radio for pets . Uh, hand shoes. Hold on a tic. We don't need the President to go to the South. We just need the troops! Let's go straight to them! If there's one thing I know about troops, it's that they love fighting .

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I know General Iroh. He might be willing to help us.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: A man on the inside. Perfect!  And you need to sell some mecha tanks. I know some people who need them. We'll ship 'em South.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: That's perfect! You'll be making money for your company and you'll be helping to defeat Unalaq.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: It's true. If you can't make money during a war, you just flat-out cannot make money.

transcript.speaker: Asami
transcript.text: It's dangerous on the seas right now, but I'm willing to try if you are.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: It'll be crazy risky, but I love crazy risky! End storm!  Zhu Li, get those other ideas to research and development. I want prototypes by next week.

transcript.speaker: Korra
transcript.text: I don't understand why it's so hard to get Republic City to support the South.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: Don't worry, I'm already working on that. As soon as people see this , they'll be lining up to fight Unalaq. Zhu Li, do the, uh-- the thing.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Don't freak out. It's not real.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
transcript.text: I had a film crew documenting the entire Northern invasion.

transcript.speaker: Bolin
transcript.text: Ahhh! Sorry. I keep doing that.

transcript.speaker: Varrick
